_exec_summary.SummaryText:
This Risk Management Plan (RMP) has been prepared by the BASF Corporation (BASF), Theodore Site to satisfy the requirements of the Clean Air Act Amendments (CAAA) Section 112 (r) mandated by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (40 CRF-part 68).  



The BASF Theodore unit is located at 4201 Evonik Road in Theodore, Mobile County, Alabama.  The site occupies approximately 2.8 Acres and will employ 21 Evonik, BASF and contract personnel.  The unit is designed, built and managed by BASF.  Startup is scheduled for August-September, 2015 when the unit will produce a chelate, methylglycinediacetic acid, for use as an additive in commercial and consumer cleaning products.  The unit is located on leased property within Evonik Corporation's Mobile Site.  Personnel, site services, some raw materials and utilities will be supplied by Evonik under various contractual arrangements.  The Trilon Unit will adhere to Evonik environmental, safety and health policies and procedures.  In addition selected BASF procedures will also be in effect.



RMP applicable chemicals utilized include Formaldehyde Solution, Anhydrous Ammonia and Hydrocyanic Acid.  Hydrocyanic acid is present in small quantities well below the applicable threshold for HCN.  HCN is not stored and is reacted to an intermediate without accumulation.  Anydrous Ammonia, a recovered by-product, is present in quantities less than than the the RMP threshold quantity.  As a conservative measure, however, Anydrous Ammonia is included in the RMP plan.  Formaldehyde solution is stored in quantities which exceed the RMP threshold quantity.



AS the BASF plant is located within the Evonik facility, the BASF unit will rely on the Evonik Emergency Response capabilities.   Evonik began production as Degussa and now produces a variety of intermediates/products for it's various business units. Approximately 1,100 Evonik and contract personnel are employed.  The site maintains fully developed environmental, safety and industrial

health procedures, policies and practice.  Both BASF and Evonik adhere to Responsible Care Management policies and procedures.  Emergency response planning, training and resources are provided by Evonik which maintains several RMP plans for their various processes.



EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM INFORMATION for the EVONIK, BASF and all 3rd Party Facilities

The Evonik program consists of procedures for responding to a release of a regulated substance, including

the possibility of a fire or explosion if a flammable substance is accidentally released. The

procedures address all aspects of emergency response, including proper first aid, medical treatment,

evacuation plans, and notification of local emergency response.

The overall emergency response program for Evonik is coordinated with the Mobile Fire

Department and the Emergency Management Agency (EMA). This coordination includes periodic

meetings of the committee, which includes local emergency response officials, local government

officials, and industry representatives. Evonik has around-the-clock communications capability with

appropriate LEPC officials and emergency response organizations (e.g., fire department). This

provides a means of notifying the public of an incident, if necessary, as well as facilitating quick

response to an incident. In addition to periodic LEPC meetings, Evonik conducts periodic

emergency drills that involve the LEPC and emergency response organizations, and the plant

provides annual refresher training to local emergency responders regarding the hazards of regulated

substances in the plant.
